metadata.title: Evolution of BBL in Instructional Design in Higher Education: Scoping review (2013-2024)
metadata.description: This study aims to analyze the evolution of brain-based learning and its connection to instructional design in global higher education, utilizing a bibliometric analysis of publications in the Scopus and Web of Science databases from January 2013 to March 2024. The examination of the texts included VOSviewer, Excel, and Visme software.  The review recorded the development and geographical dispersion of the literature, while also delineating the ideological framework of BBL and instructional design in higher education.
metadata.method:
Explanation of existing data

The timeframe selected for this evaluation is the past decade, which spans from January 2013 to March 2024, comprising a decade and three months. Scopus and Web of Science (WOS) were the databases employed, as they are the most frequently employed for bibliometric analysis (Pranckutė, 2021). The review protocol was designed based on the type of study. The methodology and guidelines recommended by the Joanna Briggs Institute (Peters et al., 2020) as cited in Medina-Córdoba et al. (2023) were followed, as well as the PRISMA reporting guidelines "Extension for Scoping Reviews (PRISMA-ScR)" (Tricco et al., 2018 cited by Medina-Córdoba et al. 2023).

 

Data collection procedures

Source identification for this study will be conducted according to the Preferred Reporting Criteria for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) guidelines, which detail procedures for identifying papers for inclusion in systematic analyses of research reviews (Page et al., 2021). The review will focus on articles published in journals indexed in Scopus and Web of Science (WOS) in both English and Spanish. Conference papers, conference proceedings, books and book chapters will be excluded, since articles from peer-reviewed journals go through a more rigorous publication process and are considered more reliable in the academic field (Hallinger, 2020).

 

Stopping rule

The size of the articles will be controlled by the number of articles that the time frame chosen for this scoping review yields, which covers the last ten years (January 2013 to March 2024 - one decade and 3 months) in the databases that will be used, Scopus and Web of Science (WOS).

data.title: Evolution of BBL in Instructional Design in Higher Education: Scoping review (2013-2024)

metadata.title: Implementing UML Models, Principles of Knowledge Representation and Bitcoin Blockchain Technology to Enhance Transparency of Property Payments and Property Registries and Property Transfers Based in the Brazilian Real Estate Registration System
metadata.description: Objective: This paper proposes a Solution Concept based on Bitcoin Blockchain technology to aid in solving the problem of transparency in the Brazilian Real Estate Registry System by registering Property Payments, Property Registries (Ownership), and Property Transfers on the Bitcoin Blockchain. Methods: This paper develops the Solution Concept using Unified Modeling Language (UML) diagrams, Principles of Knowledge Representation and it uses the Testnet3 and Signet Networks of the Bitcoin Blockchain to implement the Solution Concept using the Bitcoin Core’s full node and wallet, and the Bitcoin Ordinal Software Utility. Results: Through the Solution Concept, it is verified that there would be more certainty and security in the Brazilian Real Estate Registry System when Property Payments are made in bitcoin. Additionally, it is verified that provenance and digital thread of Property Registries would be assured if they were registered on the Bitcoin Blockchain. Lastly, the Bitcoin Blockchain Testnet3 Network also endures the same scalability issues as the Bitcoin Blockchain Mainnet Network, with delayed confirmation times of payment, Property Registry, and Property Transfer transactions. Conclusions: The Bitcoin Blockchain adds transparency to the Brazilian Real Estate Registry System because Property Payments, Property Registry (Ownership), and Property Transfers registered on the Bitcoin Blockchain are public, traceable, and immutable (Bitcoin.org, n.d.-c). Although the Bitcoin Blockchain Network endures with scalability issues, it was verified that this is due to Bitcoin Blockchain’s public network design that prioritizes decentralization and security over scalability within the realm of the Blockchain Trilemma (Nakai et al., 2024, p. 80560).

data.title: Implementing UML Models, Principles of Knowledge Representation and Bitcoin Blockchain Technology to Enhance Transparency of Property Payments and Property Registries and Property Transfers Based in the Brazilian Real Estate Registration System

metadata.title: Global Simulations Suggest Biomass Burning Aerosols are Regionally Important Ice Nucleating Particles
metadata.description: This repository supplements the research article titled "Global Simulations Suggest Biomass Burning Aerosols are Regionally Important Ice Nucleating Particles" and contains - 1. Postprocessed simulation results from running the UK Met Office Unified Model (UM); the rose suites are stated in the accompanying manuscript, 2. Processed measurement data from the DOE- and NSF-funded campaigns, and 3. Python scripts used to prepare INP plots and analyses presented in the paper.

data.title: Global Simulations Suggest Biomass Burning Aerosols are Regionally Important Ice Nucleating Particles

metadata.title: Revised evaluation artifact for the Modelizer framework described in "Learning Program Behavioral Models from Synthesized Input-Output Pairs"
metadata.description:
This package contains the revised evaluation artifact for Modelizer - a framework for learning models from BlackBox systems using Input-Output examples.

It consists of the following zip archives:

  1. train.zip: synthetic data used for the model training
  2. test.zip: synthetic and extracted real data used for the model evaluation 
  3. eval.zip: evaluation results (experiment results and notebooks with the analysis of the results)
  4. eval_llm.zip: evaluation results for experiments with LLMs
  5. models.zip: all the models that were trained during the experiments
  6. llm_fine_tuned_models.zip: weights of fine-tuned the LLMs
  7. llm.zip: subset of training data for experiments with LLMs
  8. plots.zip: plots of the evaluation results and code to generate them

You can find the framework implementation and usage instructions at https://github.com/2ral/Modelizer

data.title: Revised evaluation artifact for the Modelizer framework described in "Learning Program Behavioral Models from Synthesized Input-Output Pairs"

metadata.title: Draft genome sequence of Alicyclobacillus acidocaldarius strain LH1 isolated from an Andean solfataric field
metadata.description:
Annotation data for assembly GCA_040779485.1 available in the GenBank database.

Annotation of assembly GCA_040779485.1 using the bioinformatics programs CRISPRCasFinder, mobileOG-db v1.1.3. and VirSorter v2.2.4. The results of the programs are made available through their output documents.

metadata.title: Maximizing the potential of numerical weather prediction models: lessons learned from combining high-performance computing and cloud computing
metadata.description:
To promote cloud and HPC computing, GRAPEVINE* project objectives include using these tools
along with open data sources to provide a reusable IT service. In this service a predictive model based on Machine
learning (ML) techniques is created with the aim of preventing and controlling grape vine diseases in the
wine cultivation sector. Aside from the predictive ML, meteorological forecasts are crucial input to train the
ML models and on a second step to be used as input for the operational prediction of grapevine diseases. To this
end, the Weather and Research Forecasting model (WRF) has been deployed in CESGA’s HPC infrastructure
to produce medium-range and sub-seasonal forecasts for the targeted pilot areas (Greece and Spain). The data
assimilation component of WRF – WRFDA – has been also introduced for improving the initial conditions of
the WRF model by assimilating observations from weather stations and satellite precipitation products (Integrated
Multi-satellitE Retrieval for GPM – IMERG). This methodology for assimilation was developed during
STARGATE project, allowing the testing of the methodology in the operational service of GRAPEVINE. The
operational production of the forecasts is achieved by the cloudify orchestrator on a Kubernetes cluster. The
connections between the Kubernetes cluster and the HPC infrastructure, where the model resides, is achieved
with the croupier plugin of cloudify. Blueprints that encapsule the workflows of the meteorological model and its
dependencies were created. The instances of the blueprints (deployments) were created automatically to produce
operationally weather forecasts and they were made available to the ML models via a THREDDS server. Valuable
lessons were learned with regards the automation of the process and the coupling with the HPC in terms of
reservations and operational production.

creators.name: Nieto, Francisco Javier
creators.affiliation: Atos, Research and Innovation, ATOS Spain SA, 48013 Bilbao, Spain

creators.name: González, Sergio García
creators.affiliation: Atos IT, Research and Innovation, 39011 Santander, Spain

grants.title: reSilienT fARminG by Adaptive microclimaTe managEment

data.title: Maximizing the potential of numerical weather prediction models: lessons learned from combining high-performance computing and cloud computing
